DOC.HEAD: Manson Follower Susan Atkins Denied Parole
DOC.TEXT: Susan Atkins, who fatally stabbed pregnant actress Sharon Tate during the Charles Manson ``family'' killings 20 years ago, was denied parole for a ninth time Wednesday. In rejecting her bid for release, the state parole board noted that Atkins was involved in three incidents resulting in the premeditated murder of eight people ``for the bizarre motive of starting a race war.'' Atkins, 41, who is serving a life sentence on eight murder convictions that included the 1969 Tate-LaBianca slayings, won't get another parole hearing until December 1992, the three-member board decided. Atkins, with other Manson followers, was convicted of murder and conspiracy in 1971 for the murders of Miss Tate and four others at the actress' home, and of for slayuing grocer Leno LaBianca and his wife at their home the next night. Prosecutors argued during the Manson family trial that the killings were part of Manson's plot to incite chaos, or ``Helter Skelter,'' that would result in a black vs. white civil war. Manson, who expected ultimately to take control of the country when the fighting ended, is serving a life prison sentence and has repeatedly been denied parole. Miss Tate, who was 8{ months pregnant, was stabbed 16 times by Atkins and Charles ``Tex'' Watson, who is serving a life sentence in the California Men's Colony in San Luis Obispo. Presiding Commissioner Rudolph Castro called the crimes among ``the most heinous and callous ever committed in California, if not in the nation.'' The actress' mother, Doris Tate, addressed the board. ``Anyone has an alternative to do right. I don't understand why anyone would murder an innocent pregnant woman,'' she said. ``The thing that goes continually through my mind is the lack of compassion Susan had for Sharon. ``When Sharon begged for her life, Susan said, `Shut up, bitch. You're going to die.' And after they stabbed her 16 times they hung her. I have nothing but contempt for this individual.'' Prosecutor Stephen Kay, a Los Angeles County deputy district attorney, told the board the release of Atkins would be ``one of the most dangerous things this board can do.'' Atkins said she realized she might spend the rest of her life behind bars for acts she called ``unforgivable.'' ``I take the blame,'' Atkins told the board. ``Not only am I being punished, but I deserve to be punished for what I did.'' Atkins' attorney, Deborah Fraser, said although her client's crimes should not be excused, the board should put aside political considerations and offer her a release date. She cited a 1989 psychiatrist's report that found Atkins ``less dangerous than the average inmate.''
